message_text:
<paper>
Paper Title: Dynamic Event-Triggered Consensus Control for Interval Type-2 Fuzzy Multi-Agent Systems
Paper Abstract: This study investigates a fuzzy consensus problem for nonlinear multi-agent systems (MASs) with parameter uncertainties via dynamic event-triggered mechanism. The interval type-2 (IT2) fuzzy systems are used to model MASs, and a dynamic event-triggered fuzzy controller is presented. A Lyapunov-Krasovskii functional is constructed in which the sampling property is included, based on which the sufficient condition is determined for dynamic event-triggered fuzzy controller, while all agents are guaranteed to be consensus exponentially. Finally, the MASs of tunnel diode circuit and one-link manipulator are used to verify the efficiency of the presented control method, respectively.
</paper>

<paper_classification>
"contribution" = proposes something new (method, technique, dataset, framework, benchmark, etc.)
"survey" = literature review, overview, meta-analysis, position papers (only references existing work)
</paper_classification>

<entity_types>
task      - Problem being solved (image classification, theorem proving, protein folding)
method    - Technique, algorithm, procedure (gradient descent, CRISPR, induction)
data      - Datasets, databases, benchmarks (ImageNet, MNIST, arXiv corpus)
artifact  - Pre-built: trained models, proof libraries (GPT-4, Mathlib, Cas9)
tool      - Software, instruments, platforms (PyTorch, Lean prover, microscope)
concept   - Abstract ideas, theories, frameworks (attention, category theory)
other     - Entities that don't fit above categories
</entity_types>

<relations>
uses     - Anything EXISTING that the paper uses (methods, datasets, tools, concepts, tasks)
proposes - Anything NEW/NOVEL that the paper creates or introduces

VALIDATION REQUIREMENTS:
- ALL papers MUST have at least 1 "uses" (papers always build on existing work)
- CONTRIBUTION papers MUST have at least 1 "proposes" (they must create something new)
</relations>

<output_json>
{
  "paper_type": "contribution" or "survey",
  "triples": [
    {
      "name": "Wikipedia Article Title",
      "relation": "uses|proposes",
      "entity_type": "task|method|data|artifact|tool|concept|other",
      "wikipedia_url": "https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/...",
      "relevance": "Why this matters (1 sentence)"
    }
  ]
}
</output_json>

<YOUR_TODO_LIST>
FIRST, add ALL of these to your todo list with "TodoWrite" tool:

CRITICAL: Todo content must be copied exactly as is written here, with NO CHANGES. These todos are intentionally detailed so that another LLM could read each one without any external context and understand exactly what it has to do.

1. Read ./triples_output.json. Classify paper as "contribution" or "survey". Edit triples_output.json to set paper_type field.

2. List ALL triples EXPLICITLY mentioned in title/abstract. For each, determine entity_type and relation.

3. For each triple: Use WebSearch tool with allowed_domains=["en.wikipedia.org"] to search "[entity name]" to find the correct Wikipedia article. IMPORTANT: Always include allowed_domains parameter to restrict to English Wikipedia.

4. Edit triples_output.json to add all triples. For each triple:
   - name: Use the Wikipedia article title (e.g., "Gradient descent" not "gradient descent algorithm")
   - relation: how paper relates to entity (uses or proposes)
   - entity_type: one of task, method, data, artifact, tool, concept, other
   - wikipedia_url: The Wikipedia URL from search results (must start with https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/)
   - relevance: 1 sentence explaining why it matters

5. Run validation: python validate_triple_json.py

6. If validation errors: Fix the errors (use WebSearch with allowed_domains=["en.wikipedia.org"] again if needed for incorrect URLs), edit triples_output.json, and rerun validation. MUST REPEAT until validation passes.

<CRITICAL_WEBSEARCH_INSTRUCTIONS>
When using WebSearch, you MUST use the allowed_domains parameter:
WebSearch(query="[your query]", allowed_domains=["en.wikipedia.org"])

This ensures only English Wikipedia results are returned. Do NOT search without allowed_domains.
</CRITICAL_WEBSEARCH_INSTRUCTIONS>
</YOUR_TODO_LIST>

Begin now.

Here are the search results for "Consensus control":

The search results cover several related meanings of consensus and control:

## Consensus Dynamics and Multi-Agent Systems

Consensus dynamics, also known as agreement dynamics, is an area of research at the intersection of systems theory and graph theory that studies how a group of agents—such as robots, sensors, or decision-makers—interacting over a network can reach a common decision or estimate through local rules and information exchange.(no content)Consensus dynamics has applications in areas such as physiological systems, gene regulatory networks, large-scale energy systems, and coordinated control of autonomous vehicle fleets on land, in the air, or in space.

## Consensus in Computer Science

The consensus problem is a fundamental problem in controlling multi-agent systems.(no content)A fundamental problem in distributed computing and multi-agent systems is to achieve overall system reliability in the presence of a number of faulty processes, which often requires coordinating processes to reach consensus, or agree on some data value that is needed during computation.

## Consensus Decision-Making

In a broader context, consensus decision-making is a group decision-making process in which participants work together to develop proposals for actions that achieve a broad acceptance.

The term "consensus control" most commonly refers to the technical field of controlling multi-agent systems where agents must reach agreement through distributed algorithms and protocols.

Web search results for query: "Event-triggered control"

Links: [{"title":"Time-triggered architecture - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Time-triggered_architecture"},{"title":"Event (computing) - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Keystrokes"},{"title":"Time-Triggered Protocol - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Time-Triggered_Protocol"},{"title":"Maurice Heemels - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Maurice_Heemels"},{"title":"DOM event - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/DOM_Events"},{"title":"Event-driven architecture - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Event-driven_architecture"},{"title":"Event-driven programming - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Event-driven_application"},{"title":"Event-driven process chain - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Event-driven_process_chain"},{"title":"Inversion of control - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Inversion_of_control"},{"title":"Trauma trigger - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Trauma_trigger"}]

Based on the web search results, I found some relevant information about event-triggered systems in a control context:

Maurice Heemels, a Full Professor at Eindhoven University of Technology, was named Fellow of the IEEE in 2016 for contributions to analysis and design of hybrid, networked, and event-triggered systems. This indicates that event-triggered control is an active area of research in control systems.

The search results primarily returned information about related concepts like time-triggered systems, event-driven architecture, and event-driven programming. However, these are distinct from event-triggered control in the strict sense.

**Event-triggered control** in the control systems context is a control methodology where control actions are executed based on the occurrence of specific events (such as when a system state exceeds a threshold) rather than at predetermined time intervals. This approach is particularly valuable for networked and resource-constrained systems, as it can reduce communication and computational overhead while maintaining performance guarantees.

If you're looking for more detailed technical information about event-triggered control theory, applications, or recent research developments, I'd recommend searching for academic papers or specialized control systems resources, as the general web results focused more on event-driven programming and related computing concepts.

Web search results for query: "Lyapunov stability"

Links: [{"title":"Lyapunov stability - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Lyapunov_stability"},{"title":"Lyapunov function - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Lyapunov_function"},{"title":"Lyapunov equation - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Lyapunov_equation"},{"title":"Lyapunov optimization - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Lyapunov_optimization"},{"title":"Lyapunov theorem - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Lyapunov_theorem"},{"title":"Aleksandr Lyapunov - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Aleksandr_Lyapunov"},{"title":"Input-to-state stability - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Input-to-state_stability"},{"title":"Control-Lyapunov function - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Control-Lyapunov_function"},{"title":"LaSalle's invariance principle - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/LaSalle's_invariance_principle"},{"title":"Orbital stability - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Orbital_stability"}]

Here are the search results for **Lyapunov stability**:

## Overview

Lyapunov stability is named after Aleksandr Mikhailovich Lyapunov, a Russian mathematician who defended the thesis The General Problem of Stability of Motion at Kharkov University in 1892.

## Definition and Core Concept

Lyapunov stability means that if the system starts in a state in some domain D, then the state will remain in D for all time. More specifically, Lyapunov stability of an equilibrium means that solutions starting "close enough" to the equilibrium remain close enough.

## Related Stability Concepts

Asymptotic stability means that solutions that start close enough not only remain close enough but also eventually converge to the equilibrium.(no content)Near to a point of equilibrium which is Lyapunov stable the system remains stable under small disturbances.

## Lyapunov Functions

In the theory of ordinary differential equations (ODEs), Lyapunov functions, named after Aleksandr Lyapunov, are scalar functions that may be used to prove the stability of an equilibrium of an ODE.(no content)Lyapunov functions (also called Lyapunov's second method for stability) are important to stability theory of dynamical systems and control theory.

## Historical Significance

A. M. Lyapunov was a pioneer in successful endeavors to develop a global approach to the analysis of the stability of nonlinear dynamical systems by comparison with the widely spread local method of linearizing them about points of equilibrium.

Based on the search results, here's what I found about multi-agent systems:

## Definition

A multi-agent system (MAS or "self-organized system") is a computerized system composed of multiple interacting intelligent agents.

## Key Capabilities and Advantages

Multi-agent systems can solve problems that are difficult or impossible for an individual agent or a monolithic system to solve.(no content)With advancements in large language models (LLMs), LLM-based multi-agent systems have emerged as a new area of research, enabling more sophisticated interactions and coordination among agents.

## Composition and Types of Agents

The agents in a multi-agent system could equally well be robots, humans or human teams.(no content)Agents can be divided into types spanning simple to complex, including passive agents or "agent without goals" and active agents with simple goals.

## Key Characteristics

Agents are at least partially independent, self-aware, and autonomous, with decentralization where no agent is designated as controlling.

## Applications

Applications where multi-agent systems research may deliver an appropriate approach include online trading, disaster response, target surveillance and social structure modelling.

## Related Fields

Multi-agent reinforcement learning (MARL) is a sub-field of reinforcement learning that focuses on studying the behavior of multiple learning agents that coexist in a shared environment.

Links: [{"title":"Fuzzy control system - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Fuzzy_control_system"},{"title":"Fuzzy logic - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Fuzzy_logic"},{"title":"Control system - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Control_system"},{"title":"Fuzzy Control Language - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Fuzzy_Control_Language"},{"title":"IEEE 1855 - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/IEEE_1855"},{"title":"Defuzzification - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Defuzzification"},{"title":"Talk:Fuzzy control system - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Talk:Fuzzy_control_system"},{"title":"Fuzzy electronics - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Fuzzy_electronics"},{"title":"Type-2 fuzzy sets and systems - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Type-2_fuzzy_sets_and_systems"},{"title":"Genetic fuzzy systems - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Genetic_fuzzy_systems"}]

## Fuzzy Control Systems

A fuzzy control system is a control system based on fuzzy logic – a mathematical system that analyzes analog input values in terms of logical variables that take on continuous values between 0 and 1, in contrast to classical or digital logic, which operates on discrete values.

### How They Work

Fuzzy logic is used in control systems to allow experts to contribute vague rules such as "if you are close to the destination station and moving fast, increase the train's brake pressure"; these vague rules can then be numerically refined within the system.(no content)Fuzzy logic is an attempt to apply the easy design of logic controllers to the control of complex continuously varying systems.

### Historical Development

Interest in fuzzy systems was sparked by Seiji Yasunobu and Soji Miyamoto of Hitachi, who in 1985 provided simulations that demonstrated the feasibility of fuzzy control systems for the Sendai Subway. Their ideas were adopted, and fuzzy systems were used to control accelerating, braking, and stopping when the Namboku Line opened in 1987.

### Real-World Applications

Fuzzy control systems have been successfully applied to various consumer and industrial products:

- Matsushita vacuum cleaners use microcontrollers running fuzzy algorithms to interrogate dust sensors and adjust suction power accordingly.
- Hitachi washing machines use fuzzy controllers to load-weight, fabric-mix, and dirt sensors and automatically set the wash cycle for the best use of power, water, and detergent.
- Canon developed an autofocusing camera that uses a charge-coupled device (CCD) to measure the clarity of the image in six regions of its field of view and use the information provided to determine if the image is in focus. The camera's fuzzy control system uses 12 inputs and tracks the rate of change of lens movement during focusing.

## Exponential Stability

Based on the search results, here's an overview of exponential stability:

### Definition

Exponential stability is a form of asymptotic stability, valid for more general dynamical systems. More specifically, exponential stability means that solutions not only converge, but in fact converge faster than or at least as fast as a particular known rate.

### Key Characteristics

An exponentially stable LTI system is one that will not "blow up" (i.e., give an unbounded output) when given a finite input or non-zero initial condition. Additionally, the notion of exponential stability guarantees a minimal rate of decay, i.e., an estimate of how quickly the solutions converge.

### Criteria for Linear Time-Invariant (LTI) Systems

For continuous and discrete systems, exponential stability can be determined through eigenvalue analysis:

- **Continuous-time systems:** A continuous linear time-invariant system (LTI) is exponentially stable if and only if the system has eigenvalues (i.e., the poles of input-to-output systems) with strictly negative real parts (i.e., in the left half of the complex plane).

- **Discrete-time systems:** A discrete-time input-to-output LTI system is exponentially stable if and only if the poles of its transfer function lie strictly within the unit circle centered on the origin of the complex plane.

### Non-LTI Systems

Systems that are not LTI are exponentially stable if their convergence is bounded by exponential decay.

Links: [{"title":"Exponential stability - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Exponential_stability"},{"title":"Lyapunov stability - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Lyapunov_stability"},{"title":"Stability theory - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Stability_theory"},{"title":"Linear stability - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Unstable_equilibrium"},{"title":"C0-semigroup - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/C0-semigroup"},{"title":"Runge–Kutta methods - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Runge–Kutta_methods"},{"title":"Lyapunov exponent - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Lyapunov_exponent"},{"title":"Exponential integrator - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Exponential_integrator"},{"title":"Floquet theory - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Floquet_theory"},{"title":"Metzler matrix - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Metzler_matrix"}]

## Exponential Stability

Based on the search results, here's an overview of exponential stability:

### Definition

Exponential stability is a form of asymptotic stability, valid for more general dynamical systems. More specifically, exponential stability means that solutions not only converge, but in fact converge faster than or at least as fast as a particular known rate.

### Key Characteristics

An exponentially stable LTI system is one that will not "blow up" (i.e., give an unbounded output) when given a finite input or non-zero initial condition. Additionally, the notion of exponential stability guarantees a minimal rate of decay, i.e., an estimate of how quickly the solutions converge.

### Criteria for Linear Time-Invariant (LTI) Systems

For continuous and discrete systems, exponential stability can be determined through eigenvalue analysis:

- **Continuous-time systems:** A continuous linear time-invariant system (LTI) is exponentially stable if and only if the system has eigenvalues (i.e., the poles of input-to-output systems) with strictly negative real parts (i.e., in the left half of the complex plane).

- **Discrete-time systems:** A discrete-time input-to-output LTI system is exponentially stable if and only if the poles of its transfer function lie strictly within the unit circle centered on the origin of the complex plane.

### Non-LTI Systems

Systems that are not LTI are exponentially stable if their convergence is bounded by exponential decay.

Mendel - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Jerry_M._Mendel"},{"title":"Fuzzy set operations - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Fuzzy_set_operations"},{"title":"Random-fuzzy variable - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Random-Fuzzy_Variable"},{"title":"Rough set - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Rough_set"},{"title":"Fuzzy concept - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Fuzzy_concept"},{"title":"Fuzzy logic - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Fuzzy_logic"},{"title":"Category:Fuzzy logic - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Category:Fuzzy_logic"},{"title":"Fuzzy number - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Fuzzy_number"}]

Based on the web search results, here's a comprehensive overview of Type-2 Fuzzy Sets:

## Definition and Basic Characteristics

Type-2 fuzzy systems have a fluctuating membership function, while type-1 fuzzy systems work with a fixed membership function.(no content)If there is no uncertainty, a type-2 fuzzy set reduces to a type-1 fuzzy set, which is analogous to probability reducing to determinism when unpredictability vanishes.

## Mathematical Structure

The membership function of a general type-2 fuzzy set is three-dimensional, where the third dimension is the value of the membership function at each point on its two-dimensional domain, called its "footprint of uncertainty" (FOU).(no content)The FOU represents the blurring of a type-1 membership function and is completely described by its two bounding functions: a lower membership function (LMF) and an upper membership function (UMF), both of which are type-1 fuzzy sets.

## Types and Applications

Interval type-2 fuzzy sets have received the most attention because the mathematics needed—primarily interval arithmetic—is simpler than that needed for general type-2 fuzzy sets.(no content)Both kinds of fuzzy sets are being actively researched and have resulted in successful employment in various domains such as robot control.

## Historical Development

In 1999, Mendel and his students Nilesh Karnik and Qilian Liang introduced type-2 fuzzy logic systems and demonstrated that they outperform type-1 fuzzy logic systems, offering improved performance in handling uncertainties.

Links: [{"title":"Nonlinear control - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Nonlinear_control"},{"title":"Nonlinear system - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Nonlinear_system"},{"title":"Control theory - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Control_theory"},{"title":"Feedback linearization - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Feedback_linearization"},{"title":"Optimal control - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Optimal_control"},{"title":"Input-to-state stability - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Input-to-state_stability"},{"title":"Linear control - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Linear_control"},{"title":"Zero dynamics - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Zero_dynamics"},{"title":"Model predictive control - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Model_predictive_control"},{"title":"Machine learning control - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Machine_learning_control"}]

I've completed a web search for "Nonlinear systems control". Here are the key findings:

## Overview

Nonlinear control theory is the area of control theory which deals with systems that are nonlinear, time-variant, or both.(no content)It applies to more real-world systems, because all real control systems are nonlinear.

## Key Differences from Linear Control

Nonlinear control theory covers a wider class of systems that do not obey the superposition principle. Unlike linear systems that can be solved using frequency domain techniques, the mathematical techniques which have been developed to handle nonlinear systems are more rigorous and much less general, often applying only to narrow categories of systems, including limit cycle theory, Poincaré maps, Lyapunov stability theory, and describing functions.

## Analysis and Design Approaches

If only solutions near a stable point are of interest, nonlinear systems can often be linearized by approximating them by a linear system obtained by expanding the nonlinear solution in a series, and then linear techniques can be used.(no content)Nonlinear systems are often analyzed using numerical methods on computers, for example by simulating their operation using a simulation language.

## Notable Techniques

Several specialized control design approaches exist for nonlinear systems, including:

- Feedback linearization is a common strategy employed in nonlinear control to control nonlinear systems.
- Nonlinear model predictive control (NMPC) is a variant of model predictive control that is characterized by the use of nonlinear system models in the prediction.
- Machine learning control is a subfield of machine learning, intelligent control, and control theory which aims to solve optimal control problems with machine learning methods, with key applications being complex nonlinear systems for which linear control theory methods are not applicable.

Links: [{"title":"Robotic arm - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Robotic_arm"},{"title":"Manipulator (device) - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Manipulator_(device)"},{"title":"Mobile manipulator - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Mobile_manipulator"},{"title":"Industrial robot - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Industrial_robot"},{"title":"Lyappa arm - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Lyappa_arm"},{"title":"Serial manipulator - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Serial_manipulator"},{"title":"Canadarm - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Canadarm"},{"title":"Parallel manipulator - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Parallel_manipulator"},{"title":"Stanford arm - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Stanford_arm"},{"title":"Snake-arm robot - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Snake-arm_robot"}]

## Search Results: Robotic Manipulator Arm

I've found comprehensive information about robotic manipulator arms. Here's an overview of what you need to know:

### Definition and Basic Characteristics

A robotic arm is a type of mechanical arm, usually programmable, with similar functions to a human arm; the arm may be the sum total of the mechanism or may be part of a more complex robot.(no content)The links of such a manipulator are connected by joints allowing either rotational motion (such as in an articulated robot) or translational (linear) displacement.

### Key Components

The terminus of the kinematic chain of the manipulator is called the end effector and it is analogous to the human hand.

### Applications

Robotic manipulator arms have diverse applications across multiple industries:

- These robotic arms are used in manufacturing to do intricate and repetitive jobs with exceptional speed and accuracy, such as welding automotive parts and assembling electronic components.
- AI-enabled robotic arms help solve manpower shortages and boost operational efficiency in logistics and warehousing by facilitating sorting, packaging, and palletizing with improved speed and precision.
- Robotic-assisted surgeries are one example of a healthcare application where AI-driven arms increase dexterity and stability, allowing for less invasive treatments and faster recovery.

### Types of Robotic Arms

Articulated robots are the most common industrial robots. They look like a human arm, which is why they are also called robotic arm or manipulator arm.

Other types include:
- Cartesian robot / Gantry robot: Used for pick and place work, application of sealant, assembly operations, handling machine tools and arc welding. It is a robot whose arm has three prismatic joints, whose axes are coincident with a Cartesian coordinator.

### Degrees of Freedom

At least six degrees of freedom are required to enable the robot hand to reach an arbitrary pose (position and orientation) in three dimensional space.

Articulated robots are the most common industrial robots. They look like a human arm, which is why they are also called robotic arm or manipulator arm.

Other types include:
- Cartesian robot / Gantry robot: Used for pick and place work, application of sealant, assembly operations, handling machine tools and arc welding. It is a robot whose arm has three prismatic joints, whose axes are coincident with a Cartesian coordinator.

### Degrees of Freedom

At least six degrees of freedom are required to enable the robot hand to reach an arbitrary pose (position and orientation) in three dimensional space.

A robotic arm is a type of mechanical arm, usually programmable, with similar functions to a human arm; the arm may be the sum total of the mechanism or may be part of a more complex robot.(no content)The links of such a manipulator are connected by joints allowing either rotational motion (such as in an articulated robot) or translational (linear) displacement.

### Key Components

The terminus of the kinematic chain of the manipulator is called the end effector and it is analogous to the human hand.

### Applications

Robotic manipulator arms have diverse applications across multiple industries:

- These robotic arms are used in manufacturing to do intricate and repetitive jobs with exceptional speed and accuracy, such as welding automotive parts and assembling electronic components.

Links: [{"title":"Tunnel diode - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Tunnel_diode"},{"title":"Resonant-tunneling diode - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Resonant-tunneling_diode"},{"title":"Diode logic - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Diode_logic"},{"title":"Negative resistance - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Negative_resistance"},{"title":"Talk:Tunnel diode - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Talk:Tunnel_diode"},{"title":"Quantum tunnelling - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Quantum_tunnelling"},{"title":"Lambda diode - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Lambda_diode"},{"title":"Backward diode - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Backward_diode"},{"title":"Diode - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Diode"},{"title":"File:Tunnel diode symbol.svg - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/File:Tunnel_diode_symbol.svg"}]

I've completed a web search for "Tunnel diode circuit" and found comprehensive information about tunnel diodes and their circuit applications. Here's a summary of the key findings:

## What is a Tunnel Diode?

Tunnel diodes have a heavily doped PN junction that is about 10 nm wide, with the heavy doping resulting in a broken band gap where conduction band electron states on the N-side are more or less aligned with valence band hole states on the P-side.(no content)They are usually made from germanium, but can also be made from gallium arsenide, gallium antimonide (GaSb) and silicon materials.

## Key Operating Characteristics

The most important operating region for a tunnel diode is the "negative resistance" region, and the negative differential resistance in part of their operating range allows them to function as oscillators and amplifiers, and in switching circuits using hysteresis.

## Circuit Applications

Applications of tunnel diodes included local oscillators for UHF television tuners, trigger circuits in oscilloscopes, high-speed counter circuits, and very fast-rise time pulse generator circuits.(no content)Their low capacitance allows them to function at microwave frequencies, far above the range of ordinary diodes and transistors.

## Additional Uses

The operating principles of a tunnel diode logic rely on biasing of the tunnel diode and supply of current from inputs over a threshold current, to switch the diode between two states, and consequently, tunnel diode logic circuits required a means to reset the diode after each logical operation.(no content)Because of the high carrier concentration, tunnel diodes are very fast, may be used at low temperatures, high magnetic fields, and in high radiation environments, and because of these properties, they are often used in spacecraft.
